On 2 April 2011 00:09, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Brian Woolley and I are pleased to announce our new paper to appear at GECCO, "On the
> Deleterious Effects of A Priori Objectives on Evolution and Representation." You can get it
> here:
>
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/woolley_gecco11.pdf

Thanks, I definitely think this is worthy research avenue. I have a
few thoughts on the subject that I'd like to express, some more well
formed than others :)

Firstly, there is of course an objective driving evolution in the
natural world albeit a very broad one, that is, being able to survive
and for long enough to reproduce (and anything else you can do towards
increasing the chances that your offspring will survive and
reproduce). It just so happens that the natural world has an incredily
complex structure that allows for many different ways (niches) of
eking out a living with a wide range of strategies from the relatively
simple (e.g. single celled algae floating in the sea) to the more
complex (e.g. writing software for a living). It also just so happens
that the sub-environments and niches have significant overlap in terms
of the strategies that work in one can sort of work in many others. As
such there are many routes for evolution to take from simple to
complex life, not just a series of stepping stones but complex
overlapping and criss-crossing paths.

Evolution discovered eyesight independently multiple times over
because it was a recurring 'problem' in all of these evolutionary
niches and one for which a solution was 'nearby' in the encoding space
of biological genetics, the same is true for other phenomenon (flight
has been discovered independently, e.g. insects, birds, bats). This
kind of shows that the biological encoding space is perhaps less
susceptible to getting stuck than NEAT (but it does have a lot more
space-time to play with, so perhaps not that much better)

So for me the main lesson from nature is that if you wish to evolve
agents with complex strategies then you probably need to a complex
environment (fitness space) that provides a wide range of overlapping
niches and stepping stones all the way from the simple through to the
complex. So from this perspective the miracle of life on earth is due
50% to the mirace of evolution and 50% due to the miracle of the
structure of the natural world. Evolution did need large numbers to
work with (e.g. vast oceans of microscopic single celled creatures and
3.5 billion years) to make all the leaps required to get where it is,
but each of those leaps was possible because of the overlapping nature
of the available niches.

It's perhaps this latter 50% of the miracle that is generally
overlooked in evolutionary computing circles, we've tended to see the
process of evolution as the solution but have overlooked the
absolutely pivotal role of deep complexity in the fitness space.
Without that complexity probably the best you can do is to make one of
those small leaps - essentially searching a local space.

The problem with objective based search then, as I see it, is that the
objectives we have tended to focus on are too focused and rigid.


Colin
